question.content: **Complete the similarity statement.**  An equilateral triangle is  similar to a scalene triangle, because we can  map one onto the other using only dilations and rigid transformations.

options.content: sometimes
always
never
sometimes
always
never

hints.content: A pair of figures is similar if we can map one onto the other using only rigid transformations and dilations.  All rigid transformations and all dilations preserve angle measure.

An equilateral triangle always has three congruent $60\degree$ angles.  A scalene triangle always has three different angle measures because it has three different side lengths. So even if one of the angles in a scalene triangle is $60\degree$, the other two aren't.
Rigid transformations and dilations preserve angle measure, so they can never map a $60\degree$ angle onto an angle with a different measure.
An equilateral triangle is **never** similar to a scalene triangle, because we can **never** map one onto the other using only dilations and rigid transformations.

question.content: Pedro was curious if circles $A$ and $B$ (with $X$ and $Y$ being on each circle, respectively) were similar, so he tried to map one figure onto the other using rigid transformations.      Pedro concluded:    "It's not possible to map circle $A$ onto circle $B$ using a sequence of rigid transformations, so the circles are **not** similar."  **What error did Pedro make in his conclusion?**

images.alt: Two circles A and B in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The first circle has a center A at seven, three with a radius of two units and a point X on the circle at nine, three. The second circle has a center B at three, seven with a radius of one unit and a point Y on the circle at three, eight. The first circle is translated four units left and four units up to map center A prime onto center B. Point X prime is at five, seven.

options.content: One more transformation — a rotation — would map circle $A$ onto circle $B$. So the circles *are* similar.
One more transformation — a dilation — would map circle $A$ onto circle $B$. So the circles *are* similar.
There is no error. This is a correct conclusion.

hints.content: If a sequence of [[☃ definition 1]] (translations, reflections, and rotations) and dilations can map circle $A$ onto circle $B$, then the figures are **similar**.

There are many possible sequences of transformations that may map one figure onto another.  Pedro performed a translation so point $A$ coincides with point $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]  Is there another transformation (rigid or dilation) we could now use to complete the mapping?

images.alt: Two circles A and B in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The first circle has a center A at seven, three with a radius of two units and a point X on the circle at nine, three. The second circle has a center B at three, seven with a radius of one unit and a point Y on the circle at three, eight. The first circle is translated four units left and four units up to map center A prime onto center B. Point X prime is at five, seven.

hints.content: Let's try dilating by a factor of $\dfrac12$ about point $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]  The pre-image, circle $A$, maps exactly onto circle $B$.

images.alt: Two circles A and B in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The first circle has a center A at seven, three with a radius of two units and a point X on the circle at nine, three. The second circle has a center B at three, seven with a radius of one unit and a point Y on the circle at three, eight. The first circle is translated four units left and four units up to map center A prime onto center B. Point X prime is at five, seven. It is then dilated by one half to map directly onto the second circle.

hints.content: Pedro concluded:    "It's not possible to map circle $A$ onto circle $B$ using a sequence of rigid transformations, so the circles are **not** similar."  **One more transformation — a dilation — would map circle $A$ onto circle $B$. So the circles *are* similar.**

question.content: **Complete the similarity statement.**  A circle is  similar to another circle, because we can  map one onto the other using only dilations and rigid transformations.

options.content: sometimes
always
never
sometimes
always
never

hints.content: A pair of figures is similar if we can map one onto the other using only rigid transformations and dilations.  Consider circles $A$ and $B$ ($P$ is a point on circle $A$). Let's see if we can map circle $A$ onto circle $B$ using only rigid transformations and dilations.  If we succeed, we will think whether that's possible for *any* pair of circles.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two circles A and B in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The first circle has a center A at eight, two with a radius of one unit and a point P on the circle at nine, two. The second circle has a center B at four, seven with a radius of three units.

hints.content: First, we use a *translation* so $A'$, the image of point $A$, is on point $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two circles A and B in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The first circle has a center A at eight, two with a radius of one unit and a point P on the circle at nine, two. The second circle has a center B at four, seven with a radius of three units. The first circle is translated four units left and five units up to map center A prime onto center B. Point P prime is at five, seven.

hints.content: Then, we use a *dilation* about point $B$. We choose our scale factor so that $P''$, the image of point $P'$, is on circle $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]  So we were successful at mapping circle $A$ onto circle $B$ using only rigid transformations and a dilation.  In fact, we can use a similar process to map any circle to any other circle. [[☃ explanation 1]]

images.alt: Two circles A and B in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The first circle has a center A prime onto center B at four, seven. Point P prime is at five, seven. The second circle has a center B at four, seven with a radius of three units. The first circle is dilated where point a double prime is at four, seven. Point P double prime is at seven, seven.

hints.content: A circle is **always** similar to another circle, because we can **always** map one onto the other using only dilations and rigid transformations.
